body.head.byline: Special to The New York Times

block.p: LEAD: The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent company of the Great Western Bank, said today that it had agreed to acquire 13 branches and $700 million in deposits from Carteret Savings Bank in Florida.

LEAD: The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent company of the Great Western Bank, said today that it had agreed to acquire 13 branches and $700 million in deposits from Carteret Savings Bank in Florida.

The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent company of the Great Western Bank, said today that it had agreed to acquire 13 branches and $700 million in deposits from Carteret Savings Bank in Florida.

Great Western, a savings and loan association based in Beverly Hills, Calif., will pay a premium of $26.5 million for the deposits. That means Great Western will assume Carteret's $700 million in deposits, which are counted as liabilities, but will receive a check for only $673.5 million. Carteret said it would also receive $8.4 million for the offices.
The transaction, subject to regulatory approval, will increase Great Western's Florida deposits to $2.4 billion and give it more than 60 retail branches in the state.
Carteret, a New Jersey savings and loan company owned by the Ambase Corporation, will retain 10 Florida branches.
It said it had chosen to sell 13 branches to focus more on its core New Jersey operations.
While Carteret said it exceeded all regulatory capital requirements, the company noted the transaction would bolster its capital position.
Analysts said Carteret needed to raise capital because of problems in the commercial real estate market in New Jersey and other Middle Atlantic States.
